captions.text:
When I first learned that no one could ever
love me more than me

a world of happiness previously unseen was
discovered

because somewhere along the line of aging
and scrutiny and time

I was taught to despise myself
but I made sure I kept myself beautiful so

someone would love me someday
so I could belong to someone someday

because that's the most important thing a
little girl could ever want, right?

I was thirteen the first time I was embarrassed
about my body

of course it would not be the last
and I remember stuffing my bra in the morning

tears stinging my eyes
hoping, praying to something that I could

look beautiful enough today, braces and all,
for the ruthless boys

who mercilessly told me I was worthless
because my boobs weren't big enough

and I would go home and put on a sweatshirt
with my eyes closed,

deny myself the right to be shown myself,
because I didn't dare want to insinuate beauty

in regards to something so insulting as my
body.

But I mean we all end up with our heads between
our knees

because the only place we'll ever really feel
safe

is curled up inside skin we've been taught
to hate

by a society that shuns our awful confidence
and feeds us our own flaws

and sometimes when I need to meet the me that
loves me, I can't find her,

a reminder that the mirror is meant to be
a curse so I confine her in my mind

but when he or she shouts let me out
we're allowed to listen.

But it's met by a chorus of conceited
egotistical

narcissist
but since when was self solicitude a sin?

since when was loving who we are made an offense
by morons that don't matter

change this physicality and that one, don't
you dare shatter the illusion you could ever

be anything beyond paper fine flesh and flashy
teeth and fingernails

echoic accusations of not good enough, never
good enough

have you ever felt so numb that it hurts
entertain me

whore
you can't surrender to them

you gotta remember you're the only thing you'll
ever truly have

and no I don't mean your body because someday
that'll go bad no matter what you do

I mean you
I mean the way your bright eyes go wild when

you smile
and how your laughter's so melodic it's a

song
I mean the way your creativity is a compass

that leads you to what you love
and you don't need any miracle cream to keep

your passions smooth, hair free
or diet pills to slim your kindness down

and when you start to drown in these these
petty expectations

you better reexamine the miracle of your existence
because you're worth so much more than your

waistline
you're worth the beautiful thoughts you think

and the daring dreams you dream, undone and
drunk off alcohol of being

but sometimes we forget that
because we live in a word where the media

pulls us from the womb
nurses us

and teaches us our first words
skinny pretty skinny pretty

girls soft quiet pretty
boys manly muscles pretty

but I don't care whether it's your gender,
your looks, your weight, your skin, or where

your love lies
none of that matters because standards don't

define you
you don't live to meet credentials established

by a madman
you're a goddamn treasure whether you wanna

believe it or not
and maybe that's what everyone should start
looking for.

title: What Guys Look For In Girls - A Slam Poem

called me a pig. I tried to make it seem like i wasn't hurt, like i still 
hade some peide left by saying "well thank you because pigs are smart" but 
he just said that im lazy and dirty and that i roll around in my own shit. 
I was made fun of because i got tired so easily and instead of taking in 
account any possible health issues i couldn't help with they just assumed i 
was lazy because "I'm fat".﻿

comments.text:
You people do realize that this poem isn't only about girls right? She does 
acknowledge that boys are insecure too. This entire pone is about EVERYONE. 
It's dissing the society we live in, the society that says that women 
should be beautiful and thin and sweet and caring, and that men should be 
muscular and proud and tall. And I have no idea why anyone is taking this 
the wrong way. The comments that say bull like, "easy for you to say, 
you're tall, skinny beautiful, blah blah blah." Everyone has insecurities, 
it's not only the people that aren't super skinny, or tall or any of that 
crap. Even the most gorgeous person has flaws. But if I say that I think 
I'm pretty, words and insults shoot me down. What's wrong with being 
confident? So everyone is saying believe in yourself, love yourself, but 
the second I say I'm pretty, I'm called narcissistic, egotistical, ugly. 
All to bring my confidence down. This poem is beautiful and god dammit stop 
hating, because really, what's the point huh? I've had super low self 
esteem all my life, but now, who gives a shit? ﻿

I have always been puzzled that most women that I have known through my 
entire life (in Sweden) say that a lot of boys were mean to them when they 
were younger but I've always been there and been nice to them even when 
they yearned for the bad boys with obvious issues on all fronts. It's sad 
that they can't be more like me and be perfectly happy on their own without 
a need to belong to "someone" and look nice "for someone". Feminism need to 
point out more that women don't need men and don't have to look good for 
some stranger. My advice; just do your own thing and you'll just be so much 
happier. Life as a single with some good sex here and there is a perfectly 
valid option that I recommend. No extra strings attached. Then again, since 
I moved to America it sure is clear as day that you guys have a LONG way to 
go to get on Swedens level when it comes to treating women right and 
equally.﻿

comments.author: amanda smith

comments.text:
I think everyone deals with this to some degree. Take me for example: I was 
an early bloomer so to speak, and even when I was twelve years old I had a 
large chest. It honestly wasn't any better than the way you describe having 
a small chest. I felt really dowdy and unattractive because I couldn't wear 
the types of clothes that were popular with other twelve-year-old girls. 
Moreover, I didn't really know how to dress for my body type because I had 
developed so quickly, so my sense of style was less than flattering, and my 
peers didn't let me forget it. I was once told by a girl that her friend 
would have liked me better if I knew how to dress myself. That stung. In 
another instance, I remember meeting another girl my age who was also an 
early bloomer. The thing was, she was a horrible person with discipline 
problems, and she would go around harassing and even hitting the rest of 
us. I remember at one point she and I were standing in front of the sinks 
in the washroom, washing our hands, and I noticed how similar our bodies 
looked, and it was the first time in my life that I /hated/ my body. Not 
just a casual "Oh, I'm not that pretty, I wish I looked different," but a 
full-out loathing that I had a large chest. Throughout all my teenage years 
I felt that I could be so much more attractive if I had a smaller chest, 
that I'd be able to wear the clothes that I liked without embarrassing 
myself. It wasn't until I was an adult that I finally came to terms with 
it, and I certainly don't hate my chest. I've also learned to dress in 
styles that (I think) look good on me. I still have times when I think "Oh, 
that's a really nice top, if only I had smaller breasts so I could wear it 
nicely," but it's more of a minor annoyance now, rather than a full-out 
self-esteem shattering feeling.﻿

comments.text:
By Janis Ian

I learned the truth at seventeen
That love was meant for beauty queens
And high school girls with clear skinned smiles
Who married young and then retired
The valentines I never knew
The Friday night charades of youth
Were spent on one more beautiful
At seventeen I learned the truth...

And those of us with ravaged faces
Lacking in the social graces
Desperately remained at home
Inventing lovers on the phone
Who called to say "come dance with me"
And murmured vague obscenities
It isn't all it seems at seventeen...

A brown eyed girl in hand me downs
Whose name I never could pronounce
Said: "Pity please the ones who serve
They only get what they deserve"
The rich relationed hometown queen
Marries into what she needs
With a guarantee of company
And haven for the elderly...

So remember those who win the game
Lose the love they sought to gain
In debitures of quality and dubious integrity
Their small-town eyes will gape at you
In dull surprise when payment due
Exceeds accounts received at seventeen...

To those of us who knew the pain
Of valentines that never came
And those whose names were never called
When choosing sides for basketball
It was long ago and far away
the world was younger than today
when dreams were all they gave for free
to ugly duckling girls like me...

We all play the game, and when we dare
We cheat ourselves at solitaire
Inventing lovers on the phone
Repenting other lives unknown
That call and say: "Come on, dance with me"
And murmur vague obscenities
At ugly girls like me, at seventeen...﻿

other and the world. Who cares if you're "fuckable" or not? Dedicate your 
life to helping others or improving the world in some way instead.﻿

comments.author: Roxy dlas

comments.text:
Stay strong <3 I know how you feel. I have anxiety and depression and it 
sucks. Please NEVER harm yourself. You're hurting someone who loves you, 
and it doesn't do any good. I hope one day everyone will realize none of 
this matters. It doesn't matter what the media of of what people think. 
What matters is that you're happy, but nowadays, that's hard. Why? Because 
people think that it does matter what others think. You're beautiful and 
don't let anyone let you think different. :-)

comments.text:
I feel like I can be lazy and myself at home. But at school in the morning 
I half to make my hair perfect and my makeup make me look nicer just for 
school because I was so used on people hitting on me who are older, and I 
probably known they wouldn't like how I actually was (myself). So if I 
didn't go to school like that and I was myself people would think I was 
nothing and probably not popular. I still feel like that even 2 days ago ﻿

comments.author: RandomHelpingGuy

comments.text:
I don't understand how anyone male or female could see this as anything 
other than beautiful. She expressed a truth that we are becoming blind to. 
Even as men we need to help to show the new generation of young women that 
they are beautiful regardless of their looks and stop our boys from 
treating these girls like they are less than human. Women aren't a trophy 
to show off they are beautiful citizens that shape the foundation of the 
Earth's governments. We should treat them as such. ﻿
comments.author: Roderick Scott
